question: 悪因悪果
sourceMnemonic:
The <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> yields the <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>fruit</kanji>, or more simply, <vocabulary>evil breeds evil</vocabulary>.

This is a Buddhist term, often used together with <ja>善因善果</ja> (virtue breeds virtue) to illustrate the concept of karma. While not a widely known phrase, it a nice saying to remind us of the importance of our actions.
sourceReadingMnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The last <ja>悪果</ja> gets the <ja>悪</ja> shortened a little bit.
